content: The "United States Fire Administration Reauthorization Act of 2008" aims to address the high fire death rates in the country, with findings showing a significant decrease in fire-related deaths over the past 25 years but still high compared to other industrialized nations. The Act emphasizes the need for continued efforts to reduce civilian fire deaths, injuries, and direct losses, as well as to prevent firefighter fatalities. The United States Fire Administration supports fire departments through training, data collection, awareness, education, and research for fire prevention and suppression technologies. Improving data collection is crucial for tracking and responding to fire incidents effectively. The United States Fire Administration conducts research and development to enhance fire service capabilities in suppressing and preventing fires. It plays a vital role in preparing for national disasters and should have a prominent position within FEMA and DHS. Authorization of appropriations for the US Fire Administration is outlined in the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act. Section 17(g)(1) of the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is amended to allocate specific funding amounts for fiscal years 2009 to 2012. This includes funds for carrying out section 8(f) activities. Additionally, there are modifications and reporting requirements for the National Fire Academy training program. SEC. 4 of the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is amended to include tactics and strategies for dealing with natural disasters, acts of terrorism, and other man-made disasters. It also covers tactics and strategies for fighting large-scale fires or multiple fires in a general area that cross jurisdictional boundaries. The Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is amended to include tactics for fighting fires at the wildland-urban interface, fires involving hazardous materials, and advanced emergency medical services training. On-site training provisions are also updated to increase the percentage and allow contracts with organizations meeting national standards. The Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is amended to include tactics for fighting fires at the wildland-urban interface, hazardous materials fires, and advanced emergency medical services training. The Administrator must comply with national standards for fire service training programs and may only contract with organizations providing accredited training or equivalent quality programs. The organization has a satisfactory fire service training program under a cooperative agreement with a Federal agency, showing equivalent quality to described programs. There is a restriction on funds, and a requirement for triennial reports under the United States Fire Administration Reauthorization Act of 2008. The United States Fire Administration Reauthorization Act of 2008 requires triennial reports to include changes to the National Fire Academy curriculum, based on lessons learned from emergency events and exercises. Additionally, a report on providing incident command training for fires at ports and in marine environments must be submitted to Congress within a year of the Act's enactment. The report required by the United States Fire Administration Reauthorization Act of 2008 must include a description of necessary curriculum for incident command training in port and maritime environments, existing training programs, feasibility, and cost of making training available to fire service personnel. The United States Fire Administration Reauthorization Act of 2008 mandates the development of a course for fire service personnel in marine environments, including fires on water and vessels. The National Fire Incident Reporting System will be updated to allow real-time access and updates through the Internet. The United States Fire Administration Reauthorization Act of 2008 mandates updating the National Fire Incident Reporting System for real-time Internet access. Amendments include a technical correction and assistance for fire services in wildland-urban interface areas. The United States Fire Administration Reauthorization Act of 2008 mandates updating the National Fire Incident Reporting System for real-time Internet access and provides assistance for fire services in rural, remote, and wildland-urban interface areas through research and technology dissemination. The United States Fire Administration Reauthorization Act of 2008 requires the publication of research program details, including scope, methodology, funding, and results on the Administration's website. Deadlines for publishing this information are also specified. The United States Fire Administration Reauthorization Act of 2008 mandates the publication of research program information within specific timeframes. Additionally, the Act encourages the adoption of standards for firefighter health and safety. The United States Fire Administration Reauthorization Act of 2008 mandates promoting adoption of national standards for firefighter health and safety, including operations, training, staffing, and fitness. It also encourages state and local fire service representation at the national operations center. The Secretary will establish a fire service position at the National Operations Center to facilitate information sharing between the Federal Government and State/local fire services. A State or local fire service official will be designated for this position on a rotating basis, managed according to established rules. This is part of the coordination efforts for fire prevention, control, and emergency medical services. The Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is amended to emphasize coordination efforts between the Administrator and other government departments, agencies, and organizations for fire prevention and control programs. Liaison is to be provided at an appropriate level to ensure coordination with Federal, State, and local entities. The Administrator is tasked with coordinating emergency medical services programs related to fire service-based systems with various government agencies and organizations. Additionally, the Administrator is authorized to conduct best practices for fire service-based emergency medical services. The Administrator is authorized to conduct studies on the operations and management of fire service-based emergency medical services, including protocols for on-scene care, resource allocation, and training requirements. Amendments to definitions in the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 are also outlined. SEC. 11. SUPPORTING THE ADOPTION OF FIRE SPRINKLERS. Congress supports the recommendations of the United States Fire Administration regarding the adoption of fire sprinklers in commercial buildings and educational programs to raise awareness of the importance of installing fire sprinklers in residential buildings.
